## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 640, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space, \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space, \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space, \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge, \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant, \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass constant, \(u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron, \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton, \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant, \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant, \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant, \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant, \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall, \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 102, 620, 121]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 564, 242, 580]]<|/det|>

decay constant,  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 559, 145]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 524, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 193, 537, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 234, 524, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 262, 571, 295]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V} < c^2 >\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 304, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 338, 608, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - \chi^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 384, 537, 418]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 426, 625, 445]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 459, 593, 477]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 490, 528, 514]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 526, 593, 545]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 560, 625, 579]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 593, 561, 612]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 628, 581, 647]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 656, 536, 689]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 72, 544, 90]]<|/det|>
## Section A  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[298, 102, 700, 121]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the spaces provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 148, 97, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 542, 168]]<|/det|>
Explain what is meant by a geostationary orbit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 272, 875, 290]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 146, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 616, 322]]<|/det|>
A satellite of mass \(m\) is in a circular orbit about a planet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 781, 339]]<|/det|>
The mass \(M\) of the planet may be considered to be concentrated at its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 777, 354]]<|/det|>
Show that the radius \(R\) of the orbit of the satellite is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 365, 544, 406]]<|/det|>
\[R^{3} = \left(\frac{GM T^{2}}{4\pi^{2}}\right)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 838, 453]]<|/det|>
where \(T\) is the period of the orbit of the satellite and \(G\) is the gravitational constant. Explain your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 618, 876, 637]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 144, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 650, 875, 685]]<|/det|>
The Earth has mass \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\). Use the expression given in **(b)** to determine the radius of the geostationary orbit about the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[509, 850, 875, 868]]<|/det|>
<form>radius = ............................................ $m$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[868, 850, 875, 868]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
The volume of an ideal gas in a cylinder is \(1.80 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^3\) at a pressure of \(2.60 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and a temperature of \(297 \text{K}\), as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 77, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 121, 576, 282]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 305, 509, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 875, 371]]<|/det|>
The thermal energy required to raise the temperature by \(1.00 \text{K}\) of \(1.00 \text{mol}\) of the gas at constant volume is \(12.5 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 875, 416]]<|/det|>
The gas is heated at constant volume such that the internal energy of the gas increases by \(95.0 \text{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 429, 180, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 429, 276, 448]]<|/det|>
Calculate

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 460, 561, 479]]<|/det|>
1. the amount of gas, in mol, in the cylinder,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[497, 643, 876, 662]]<|/det|>
<form>amount = ............................................ mol [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 675, 500, 693]]<|/det|>
2. the rise in temperature of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[423, 860, 875, 878]]<|/det|>
<form>temperature rise = ............................................ K [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
Use your answer in **(i)** **part 2** to show that the final pressure of the gas in the cylinder is \(2.95 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 275, 875, 293]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 303, 146, 322]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 806, 323]]<|/det|>
The gas is now allowed to expand. No thermal energy enters or leaves the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 774, 337]]<|/det|>
The gas does 120J of work when expanding against the external pressure.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 839, 368]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the final temperature of the gas is above or below 297K.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 472, 875, 490]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 108]]<|/det|>
An insulated metal sphere of radius \(R\) is situated in a vacuum. The charge \(q\) on the sphere may be considered to be a point charge at the centre of the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[898, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 117, 875, 138]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 147, 875, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 180, 181, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 875, 215]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 227, 531, 246]]<|/det|>
\[C = 4\pi \epsilon_0 R.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 412, 875, 431]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 443, 146, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 512, 462]]<|/det|>
An isolated metal sphere has radius \(45 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 473, 181, 492]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 473, 875, 492]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 657, 875, 676]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[853, 657, 875, 676]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 688, 181, 707]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 688, 611, 707]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 702, 875, 736]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 750, 484, 769]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 919, 875, 938]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 292, 92]]<|/det|>
Define the _tesla_.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 873, 123]]<|/det|>
<form>Two long straight vertical wires X and Y are separated by a distance of 4.5 cm, as illustrated in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 676, 509, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 707, 556, 727]]<|/det|>
The wires pass through a horizontal card PQRS.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 722, 875, 742]]<|/det|>
The current in wire X is 6.3 A in the upward direction. Initially, there is no current in wire Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 755, 181, 772]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 754, 875, 789]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 5.1, sketch, in the plane PQRS, the magnetic flux pattern due to the current in wire X. Show at least four flux lines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 768, 875, 787]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
The magnetic flux density \(B\) at a distance \(x\) from a long straight current-carrying wire is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 119, 520, 149]]<|/det|>
\[B = \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi x}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 798, 184]]<|/det|>
where \(I\) is the current in the wire and \(\mu_0\) is the permeability of free space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 196, 792, 215]]<|/det|>
Calculate the magnetic flux density at wire Y due to the current in wire X.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 380, 876, 400]]<|/det|>
<form>flux density = ............................................. T [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 411, 181, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 411, 875, 446]]<|/det|>
A current of 9.3A is now switched on in wire Y. Use your answer in **(ii)** to calculate the force per unit length on wire Y.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 612, 876, 631]]<|/det|>
\[\text{force per unit length = ............................................ Nm}^{-1} \quad [2]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 643, 146, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 642, 591, 661]]<|/det|>
The currents in the two wires in **(b)**(iii) are not equal.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 871, 677]]<|/det|>
Explain whether the force per unit length on the two wires will be the same, or different.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 750, 875, 768]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 522, 875, 556]]<|/det|>
The input to the transformer is \(240\mathrm{V r.m.s.}\) and the maximum potential difference across the load resistor is \(9.0\mathrm{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 181, 588]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 570, 771, 588]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 121]]<|/det|>
The emission spectrum of atomic hydrogen consists of a number of discrete wavelengths. Explain how this observation leads to an understanding that there are discrete electron energy levels in atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 78, 945, 120]]<|/det|>
<form>For Examiner's Use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 257, 148, 276]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 761, 276]]<|/det|>
Some electron energy levels in atomic hydrogen are illustrated in Fig. 7.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[220, 288, 875, 606]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 625, 510, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 7.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 875, 107]]<|/det|>
The longest wavelength produced as a result of electron transitions between two of the energy levels shown in Fig. 7.1 is \(4.0 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 119, 181, 138]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 875, 199]]<|/det|>
The volume of fuel in the fuel tank of a car is monitored using a sensing device. The device gives a voltage output that is measured using a voltmeter. The variation of voltmeter reading with the volume of fuel in the tank is shown in Fig. 9.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[205, 214, 745, 453]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 749, 875, 784]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 803, 230]]<|/det|>
The attenuation of a parallel beam of X-ray radiation is given by the expression

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 240, 524, 274]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{I}{I_0} = \mathrm{e}^{-\mu X}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 289, 875, 325]]<|/det|>
where \(\mu\) is the linear attenuation (absorption) coefficient and \(x\) is the thickness of the material through which the beam passes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 337, 243, 356]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[225, 700, 833, 734]]<|/det|>
fraction \(\frac{I}{I_0}\) of intensity transmitted through soft tissue of thickness \(6.0 \text{cm}\)
